instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a MacBook here that does not want to turn on. On the charger, I can see 0.04 amps for a split second then 0 amps for a few seconds and then it cycles again. No signs of liquid damage. Where do I even begin?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts (0.398 resistance to ground when off)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3H_T</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3HRTC_X</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0 volts 

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>SMC_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S3</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts

Any advice?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message: As usual for T2 machines, start with DFU mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message: Thanks. It is likely T2, I will look into DFU mode. Under the thermal camera, T2 and the SSD's are the only chips heating up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message:
When trying to revive T2 in DFU mode I get the following message.

[B]The System cannot be restored on this device.[/B]

The operation couldn’t be completed. (AMRestoreErrorDomain error 6 - Failed to handle message type StatusMsg (Operation failed)) [AMRestoreErrorDomain – 0x6 (6)]

This happens on the last step of the revive process.

And just a few more measurements:
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 2.5 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0.9 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message:
There could be a problem with T2, or SSD.
Did you try both revive/restore options?
Don't try restore, if there is important data on its SSD; it will be erased.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message:
I tried restore option just now - confirmed with customer for approval. The message shown is the exact same as if I were to do a revive.

[B]The System cannot be restored on this device.[/B]

The operation couldn’t be completed. (AMRestoreErrorDomain error 6 - Failed to handle message type StatusMsg (Operation failed)) [AMRestoreErrorDomain – 0x6 (6)]

Is this something I should just close up? Or are there some signals I should check out first?

Thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message:
Check the voltage on all <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> surrounding coils.
Also be sure no short to ground on any big coil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20 volts on charger - 0.04 amps
threads.message: Am having same problem but Error9 in my case.
